metadata.title: The Effects of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 on the Southern Seamless Hosiery and Lumber Industries

relevance.topic: The impact of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 on southern industries
relevance.relevance: The study examines the impact of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, which imposed a minimum wage, on employment and technological changes in the southern seamless hosiery and lumber industries, highlighting labor displacement due to regulatory changes.

design.sample_characteristics: Southern seamless hosiery and lumber industries

dependent_variables.displaced: Job losses were concentrated in low-wage firms, particularly in the South.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: Employment decreased in low-wage firms, particularly in the South.
dependent_variables.wage_changes: Wages increased significantly in low-wage firms to comply with the FLSA.

key_themes: Impact of minimum wage on employment
Technological change due to wage legislation
text_fragments: 'The [FLSA] as a whole presents itself to us as a reincarnation of the NRA in a more virulent form.'
'A flat minimum price means paying a sorry slow-moving, devil-may-care, good-for-nothing specimen as much as a good man that is worth two to five times as much anywhere-anytime.'
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes how the FLSA led to increased mechanization in the seamless hosiery industry and evasion of wage laws in the lumber industry.

historical_context.economic_conditions: The period was marked by regulatory changes and war-related economic conditions.
historical_context.institutional_context: The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 imposed a minimum wage, affecting labor markets in the South.

outcomes.main_findings: The FLSA led to increased mechanization in the seamless hosiery industry and evasion of wage laws in the lumber industry, with differing impacts on employment.
outcomes.conclusions: The FLSA had significant impacts on employment and production processes in low-wage southern industries, with increased mechanization in hosiery and evasion in lumber.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The FLSA may have made foreign imports more competitive, potentially affecting long-term industry viability.
